Answer: We can cure many kinds of cancers already, and some cancers that were regularly terminal are now treatable to the point where individuals have a normal life (CLL, for example).Type 2 Diabetes is routinely cured with bariatric surgery.The obstacles facing us are not insurmountable. We put people on the moon 50 years ago, and we had just developed powered flight 50 years before that.Medical research and technology are not inhibited by complexity as much as by inconsistent funding, profit motives, and fundamental resistance to the idea of relief from the diseases of aging.There is a very interestWe can cure many kinds of cancers already, and some cancers that were regularly terminal are now treatable to the point where individuals have a normal life (CLL, for example).Type 2 Diabetes is routinely cured with bariatric surgery.The obstacles facing us are not insurmountable. By the time a cancer is noticed it consists of, at least, a billion cells. That’s a billion individuals. Once a cell mutates to become a cancer cell, it doesn’t stop mutating. Answer: Many types of cancer have been cured by surgical removal. However, cancer is a very difficult set of diseases. And I meant diseaseThe difficulty arises because each cancer is a population of billions of cells. A billion cells is about the lower limit of detection with MRI or CT. Each of those cells is different. I attended a talk where the speaker had used genomics in the form of DNAseq to map the mutations within melanoma cancers on patients, looking for some set of gene mutations common to every melanoma. Or, alternatively, he was loMany types of cancer have been cured by surgical removal. However, cancer is a very difficult set of diseases. And I meant diseaseThe difficulty arises because each cancer is a population of billions of cells. A billion cells is about the lower limit of detection with MRI or CT. Each of those cells is different. I attended a talk where the speaker had used genomics in the form of DNAseq to map the mutations within melanoma cancers on patients, looking for some set of gene mutations common to every melanoma. Or, alternatively, he was looking for “personalized therapy”. He didn’t find the common set of mutations. Instead, within a melanoma from a single patient he found overThe problem is that a treatment that kills, say, 99.999% of the cancer cells still leaves a thousand cancer cells alive. These are the ones resistant to the treatment. Now they divide. All the daughter cells inherit the resistance.Cancer and cancer treatments are natural selection in action. During my career I have been at meetings and seen 3 jaw dropping “cures”. In each case, a wide variety of cancers — lung, brain, breast, adrenal, etc. — were “cured”. However, none of these treatments ever showed up in wide-spread clinical use. Why?Today physicians are using combination therapies. If chemotherapy, then they are using 2 or more agents, under the theory that a cancer cell won’t be resistant toThe definitive cure for cancer is surgical removal. However, even if the main tumor is surgically removed, there is the chance that some cancer cells were outside the volume removed. Many cancers, of course, are not amenable to surgery. There are more and more treatments coming online exploiting the weakness of individual cancers. The treatments based on immunotherapy show promise. However, 2 of those jaw-dropping “cures” I saw were based on immunotherapy.There will be progress, particularly now that much research is focused on individual cancers, not cancer as a whole. Treatments are being devised for a particular cancer, not cancer as a whole.But as long as natural selection is true, I am pessimistic about a wholesale “cure” of cancer.

Answer: Cancer is not a disease. It’s a name for a whole family of different diseases with different causes and different biochemistries, all of which have only one thing in common: unrestrained cell growth.Some cancers already are treated. Others are not. Of the ones that are not, some will probably be treatable in the future.
name: Stewart Cook
question: https://www.quora.com/Will-it-ever-be-possible-to-cure-chronic-disorders-such-as-cancer-and-diabetes-with-advanced-technology-in-the-future

Answer: Cancer is inherently impossible to turn into a chronic condition that can be managed long-term, because its genomic instability gives it the power of natural selection: the longer it survives, the more certain it is to find new ways to outwit the shackles that are stopping it from growing. This was somehow forgotten 50-odd years ago, when oncologists triggered the War On Cancer in the USA by convincing themselves, and then the government, that cancer could be defeated within a decade - and the WOC was certainly a good thing, so sometimes even delusions can have silver linings - but “delusion”Cancer is inherently impossible to turn into a chronic condition that can be managed long-term, because its genomic instability gives it the power of natural selection: the longer it survives, the more certain it is to find new ways to outwit the shackles that are stopping it from growing. This was somehow forgotten 50-odd years ago, when oncologists triggered the War On Cancer in the USA by convincing themselves, and then the government, that cancer could be defeated within a decade - and the WOC was certainly a good thing, so sometimes even delusions can have silver linings - but “delusion” is honestly no exaggeration.However, all that means is that we need a bona fide cure, nothing less - and that may be much less far off than most people think. First, there is the burgeoning field of cancer immunotherapy, which has already seen massive success in the past decade (after quite a few decades of not seeing any) and is continuing to progress rapidly. Then there is the one thing that all cancers have in common, namely telomere elongation; a way to kill cells that are elongating their telomeres is entering clinical trials right now. Fingers crossed.

Answer: Several countries are currently working on Quantum Radar.This radar will change air defense and air operations over hostile terrain immensely.This system involves paired couplings which are two protons that are entangled with each other. This state has been described as “spooky action at a distance”. The two particles are “linked” regardless of physical distance between them. What happens to one particle, affects the other in the same fashion.A pair is generated and one half (the signal) is fired down range and the second (the idler) is kept and observed. If the “signal” hits something, the “iSeveral countries are currently working on Quantum Radar.This radar will change air defense and air operations over hostile terrain immensely.This system involves paired couplings which are two protons that are entangled with each other. This state has been described as “spooky action at a distance”. The two particles are “linked” regardless of physical distance between them. What happens to one particle, affects the other in the same fashion.A pair is generated and one half (the signal) is fired down range and the second (the idler) is kept and observed. If the “signal” hits something, the “idler” will indicate this. But it gets better. The information that the “idler” can provide is more than usually received with radars currently in use. A standard radar shows the object as a “blob” with a given speed, bearing and altitude. Features of the object are not visible. With quantum radar, the individual features of the object will be noticeable, so a radar operator will be able to identify whether the object is missile, fighter, etc and what type of missile or fighter based on the shape of the object. It could tell the difference between a US F-15 and a Russian Su-35.Here is an image of a B-2 bomber and a bird.(image fromThat is not all. The object being seen by the radar will not be able to detect that it has been detected. Currently, radars send out pulses that bounce off the object and return to the radar system. That signal is detectable at much greater ranges than a measurement return signal can, so a radar can be detected long before it could detect you out of the background noise of signals it receives. This is how a “fuzz buster” radar detector works. With quantum radar, there is almost noway to detect the signal from the radar.Next, the shape of the object will have little effect on the entangled particles. In other words, stealthy features on the object will have no effect on its detection. You could have radar cross section of a golf ball and still be as a detectable as billboard.Even if you detect the signal from a quantum radar (very remote chance), you will not be able to locate the radar itself. Currently, radars are easily located if they are broadcasting. It is like they are shining a flashlight in a dark room. You can see the flashlight and know where the person is, what they are looking at and judge whether they could see you. With quantum radar, you can not track the radar signal back to its sources. This will make suppression of enemy air defense (SEAD or Wild Weasel) missions a lot more difficult to execute.So you have a radar that works against stealthy and non-stealthy object equally, cannot be detected or tracked if detected.

The Navigation software may plot that on a chart or convert it to another format like eastings and northings but it is basically just a position. A echosounder gives you the depth under your keel, though some E/S’s will look forward for a short distance, usually not far enough ahead to stop the vessel.GPS becomes less valuable as more and more landmarks are visible, such as entering a harbor. What is of far greater importance are the channel buoys.What the pilot brings to the table is a vast depth of local knowledge. He knows the currents andGPS gives you a position in latitude and longitude. The Navigation software may plot that on a chart or convert it to another format like eastings and northings but it is basically just a position. A echosounder gives you the depth under your keel, though some E/S’s will look forward for a short distance, usually not far enough ahead to stop the vessel.GPS becomes less valuable as more and more landmarks are visible, such as entering a harbor. What is of far greater importance are the channel buoys.What the pilot brings to the table is a vast depth of local knowledge. He knows the currents and how the weather and tides affect them. He knows the local conditions. Things like did that sandbar shift after the last storm or since your chart was printed. He know areas that should be avoided. The Potato Patch just outside of San Francisco harbor is a prime example.If a ship runs aground at the harbor entrance it could cripple the harbor for days. The cost of ships and their cargo could run into 100s of millions of dollars. Having to close a harbor could cost the local economy billions. The pilot, due to his knowledge of the area, lessons the chance of that occurring.

Was the gradual evolution of language a “technological” advance - or a result of biological evolution? Was the discovery of penicillin really a “discovery” or merely a lucky accident coupled with good observations?Can we count mathematics (as a whole) - when it’s really a millon individual discoveries that built over time into one of the greatest tools we have for understanding the universe?Are negative outcomes worth more than positive ones?CONCLUSION:Questions like this cause every person to come up with a different set of wild-assed guesses as to what was the biggest effect.In the end it’s all personal opinions - and NOBODY is right…myself included.There is no good answer to this question.

Answer: How far can technology really go?I think the term “technology” is interesting when one considers it to represent, to us now anyway, a leading frontier of human innovation. Technology during the various ages of human development is often used to define the age too. When the level of technology progresses too much, we usually refer to that as a different “age” in human history.When one considers how rapidly every field of human knowledge is advancing today, we realize we are “breaking the scale we use to measure ages”. We’re not just creating new inventions faster at this point in human history,How far can technology really go?I think the term “technology” is interesting when one considers it to represent, to us now anyway, a leading frontier of human innovation. Technology during the various ages of human development is often used to define the age too. When the level of technology progresses too much, we usually refer to that as a different “age” in human history.When one considers how rapidly every field of human knowledge is advancing today, we realize we are “breaking the scale we use to measure ages”. We’re not just creating new inventions faster at this point in human history, we are at a creative and innovation point of development where the “curve of advancing technologies” is starting to appear vertical. We don’t quite know how to describe this situation.I think we need to adopt a more inclusive social contract in society as a whole before our technology can progress beyond what our pop culture science fictions have projected. Frankly, I think “technology” can take us “all the way” beyond being human, but that type of technology is going require several revolutions in our social contracts between one another to happen. We’re spending far too much attention on security and warfare, where that attention spent on more productive activities could have ended any reasons for our geopolitical tensions a generation ago.At this point in our development, with the new technologies curve appearing vertical, the only thing holding us back is our maturity as a species.

Answer: Thanks for asking me to answer this one.I can only answer from the perspective of an Israeli military professional of course, and I guess that alongside some of the wonderful answers given already, such as those byAs you can very clearly see here:Thanks for asking me to answer this one.I can only answer from the perspective of an Israeli military professional of course, and I guess that alongside some of the wonderful answers given already, such as those byAs you can very clearly see here:​This military is comprised of 1.3 Million enlisted soldiers, and another 900,000 in reserves.Fancy uniforms and nice drills for YouTube are all very nice, but what separates quality forces from others is​​​Reserves are well trained and well equipped too - granted, not to the extent Israeli Defense Forces are,While I have not had the pleasure of training alongside Indian counterparts, my peers which have, describe Indian ground forces officers asIndia's unique positioning allows its army to enjoy some of the best of what both West and East have to offer.Take the armor corps for example, which I can especially relate to, being part of the Israeli one: 4,000 tanks strong, mainly based on soviet tanks ranging from the T-90, and T-72, to improved versions of the older T-55's, the corps also operate the self produced Arjun MBT MK-1 tank - not too shabby at all (and MK 2 is now being moved into production).​​A drawback of the Indian army is its APCs (Armored personnel carrier), though it has thousands of them, they are of outdated models, but I must point out this is something many military forces have neglected over the past decades.(As an anecdote, Israel itself has the same issue and has recently devised a solution in the form of theIndia's Navy is a force to be reckoned with too.​Comprised of 2 aircraft carriers, with a navy air branch made of marine compatible , Mig 29s, 15-20 missile boats, armed with Israeli-Indian MRSAM missiles and equipped with over a thousand cruise missiles, some capable of carrying nuclear warheads, dozens of other ships as well as several submarines - some of which reported to be with nuclear launch capabilities, and a global presence (Indian Navy harbors in many allied ports, including the Israeli Navy one in Eilat, south of Israel, Red Sea), this is a serious navy.It also includes India's finest special forces unit:Without elaborating too much, MARCOS are highly appreciated by the Israelis that need to know.Lastly, the Air is another front where one should not seek a conflict with India. Israeli Air force personnel fondly speak of it as "the other IAF".One of the best equipped air forces in the world along with professional standards, courageous and well trained pilots, the IAF is also the fourth largest air force in the world with approximately 170,000 personnel and 1,400 aircraft - another example of East and West mix - including: Mirage 2000, Sukhoi 30, Mig 29 and 27, as well as Israeli drones and Falcon Intel aircraft systems.​Indian air defense is also very tight and one of its key elements is another Israeli-Indian cooperation: The Barak 8 missile.So in a nut shell, I wouldn't go as far as saying this is common Israeli knowledge. But most Israelis know that India is a military superpower, and Israeli Military professionals know exactly why this is true.As I often heard,
